headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: France: Trial Raises Algerian Ghosts

lead_paragraph: An 83-year-old retired general went on trial, accused of condoning torture and executions he and his troops carried out during Algeria's war of independence in the late 1950's and early 1960's. Paul Aussaresses, whose memoirs caused a furor when published last spring and who was stripped of national honors by President Jacques Chirac, told the court of the atrocities he recounted and said he had kept a record of them in a diary. In his book and in subsequent statements he defended the torture and summary execution of revolutionaries in Algeria, saying that the French government knew what went on and that he was only carrying out orders to protect French lives. He faces a maximum of five years in prison if convicted.
abstract: Paul Aussaresses, 83-year-old retired French general, goes on trial, accused of condoning torture and executions he and his troops carried out during Algeria's war of independence in late 1950's and early 1960's; he claims French government knew what was going on and that he was only carrying out orders to protect French lives (S)
